ai_summary.Response:
This commit primarily updates documentation related to Microsoft Entra ID governance. Key changes include:

*   **Lifecycle Workflows:** The documentation for the "Remove all access package assignments for user" task has been enhanced to include the new functionality of configuring a delay (days until expiration) before assignments are removed.
*   **Privileged Identity Management (PIM):** Updates were made to the PIM documentation regarding assigning roles, clarifying how to assign custom roles with administrative unit scope and correcting a link.
*   **Image Updates:** A minor update was made to an image file related to Identity Protection workbooks.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates the documentation for Privileged Identity Management (PIM) on how to add roles to users. The primary changes include:

*   The `ms.date` metadata has been updated to `08/29/2025`.
*   Clarification has been added regarding the assignment of custom roles with administrative unit scope. It now explains that such assignments must be initiated from within the administrative unit itself, rather than the "Roles & admins" page, and provides a link to the relevant guidance.

ai_summary.Response: The commit modifies the documentation for adding roles to users in Privileged Identity Management. It clarifies that custom roles compatible with administrative units cannot be assigned with an administrative unit scope directly from the "Roles & admins" page. Instead, users must first navigate to the specific administrative unit before assigning the role. The change also updates a link related to the creation and deletion of administrative units.

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for **Remove all access package assignments for user** task within Microsoft Entra lifecycle workflows. The key change is the addition of a new configurable parameter, `daysUntilExpiration`, which allows administrators to specify a delay before all access package assignments are removed. This provides greater flexibility in managing user access during offboarding or other lifecycle events.

If you want to see the full audit history of activity in your organization in Microsoft Entra ID including administrator, end user, and synchronization activity, you can use the [Microsoft Entra security and activity reports](~/identity/monitoring-health/overview-monitoring-health.md).\n+You can use the Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) audit history to see role assignments changes and activations done through PIM. Data is available for the past 30 days. If you want to retain audit data for longer than the default retention period, you can use Azure Monitor to route it to an Azure storage account. For more information, see [Archive Microsoft Entra logs to an Azure storage account](~/identity/monitoring-health/howto-archive-logs-to-storage-account.md). To see full audit history of Microsoft Entra ID activity including administrator, end user, and synchronization activity, you can use the [Microsoft Entra security and activity reports](~/identity/monitoring-health/overview-monitoring-health.md).\n \n Follow these steps to view the audit history for Microsoft Entra roles.\n \n ## View resource audit history\n \n+Use **Resource audit** blade to view all activity associated with your Microsoft Entra role assignment and PIM Policy management in PIM.\n \n-Resource audit gives you a view of all activity associated with your Microsoft Entra roles.\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Privileged Role Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#privileged-role-administrator).\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as a Global Administrator, Global Reader, Privileged Role Administrator, Security Administrator, or Security Reader.\n \n 1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Privileged Identity Management** > **Microsoft Entra roles**.\n \n 1. Select **Resource audit**.\n \n 1. Filter the history using a predefined date or custom range.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/azure-pim-resource-rbac/rbac-resource-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra role audit list with filters.\":::\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/pim-how-use-audit-log/resource-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra role audit list with filters.\":::\n \n ## View my audit\n \n-My audit enables you to view your personal role activity.\n+Use **My audit** blade to view your role activity for Microsoft Entra role assignment and PIM Policy management.\n \n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Privileged Role Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#privileged-role-administrator).\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com).\n \n 1. Browse to **ID Governance** > **Privileged Identity Management** > **Microsoft Entra roles**.\n \n-1. Select the resource you want to view audit history for.\n-\n 1. Select **My audit**.\n \n 1. Filter the history using a predefined date or custom range.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/azure-pim-resource-rbac/my-audit-time.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Audit list page for the current user.\":::\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/pim-how-use-audit-log/my-audit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Audit list page for the current user.\":::\n \n ## Next steps\n "

    "sha": "4b9f1a3654ff14730c15aa38e4e1fb2875332ad5",

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/4e6d4e16e5723a1aa97ab9f67e9761a97a19d7fc/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md",

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md?ref=4e6d4e16e5723a1aa97ab9f67e9761a97a19d7fc",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,236 @@\n+---\n+title: Understand Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication Certificate revocation list\n+description: Learn how certificate revocation list works with Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.subservice: authentication\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 08/26/2025\n+ms.author: justinha\n+author: vimrang\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.reviewer: vranganathan\n+ms.custom: has-adal-ref, sfi-image-nochange\n+ms.localizationpriority: high\n+---\n+\n+# Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication Certificate Revocation List (CRL)\n+\n+A Certificate Revocation List (CRL) is a list of certificates that have been revoked by the issuing Certificate Authority (CA) before their scheduled expiration date. CRLs are essential for maintaining authentication integrity. When a certificate is revoked, itâ€™s marked as untrusted even if not expired. Incorporating CRLs in certificate-based authentication ensures only valid, non-revoked certificates are accepted, and Microsoft Entra ID blocks any attempt using a revoked certificate.\n+\n+CRLs are digitally signed by the CA and published to publicly accessible locations, allowing them to be downloaded over the internet to verify the revocation status of certificates. When a client presents a certificate for authentication, the system checks the CRL to determine if the certificate has been revoked. \n+\n+If the certificate is found in the CRL, the authentication attempt is rejected. CRLs are usually updated periodically, and organizations should ensure they have the latest version of the CRL to make accurate decisions about certificate validity. \n+\n+In Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication (CBA), when CRLs are configured, the system must retrieve and validate the CRL during authentication. If Microsoft Entra ID cannot access the CRL endpoint, authentication fails because the CRL is required to confirm certificate validity.\n+\n+## How a CRL works in certificate-based authentication\n+\n+A CRL works by providing a mechanism to check the validity of certificates used for authentication. The process involves several key steps:\n+\n+- **Certificate Issuance:** When a certificate is issued by a CA, it is valid until its expiration date unless it is revoked earlier. Each certificate contains a public key and is signed by the CA.\n+- **Revocation:** If a certificate needs to be revoked (for example, if  the private key is compromised or the certificate is no longer needed), the CA adds it to the CRL.\n+- **CRL Distribution:** The CA publishes the CRL to a location accessible by clients, such as a web server or a directory service. The CRL is typically signed by the CA to ensure its integrity.\n+- **Client Check:** When a client presents a certificate for authentication, the system retrieves the CRL for each CA in the certificate chain from its published locations and checks for any revoked CAs. If any CRL location is unavailable, authentication fails because the system cannot verify the certificateâ€™s revocation status.\n+- **Authentication:** If the certificate is found in the CRL, the authentication attempt is rejected, and the client is denied access. If the certificate is not in the CRL, the authentication proceeds as normal.\n+- **CRL Updates:** The CRL is updated periodically by the CA, and clients should ensure they have the latest version to make accurate decisions about certificate validity. The system does cache the CRL for a certain period to reduce network traffic and improve performance, but it does also check for updates regularly.\n+\n+## Understanding the certificate revocation process in Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication\n+\n+The certificate revocation process enables Authentication Policy Administrators to revoke a previously issued certificate so it can't be used for future authentication. \n+\n+\n+Authentication Policy Administrators configure the CRL distribution point during the setup process for trusted issuers in the Microsoft Entra tenant. Each trusted issuer should have a CRL that you can reference by using an internet-facing URL. For more information, see [Configure Certificate Authorities](./how-to-certificate-based-authentication.md#step-1-configure-the-cas-with-a-pki-based-trust-store).\n+\n+Microsoft Entra ID supports only one CRL endpoint and supports only HTTP or HTTPS. We recommend using HTTP instead of HTTPS for CRL distribution. CRL checks occur during certificate-based authentication, and any delay or failure in retrieving the CRL can block authentication. Using HTTP minimizes latency and avoids potential circular dependencies caused by HTTPS (which itself requires certificate validation). To ensure reliability, host CRLs on highly available HTTP endpoints and verify that they're accessible over the internet.\n+ \n+>[!IMPORTANT]\n+>The maximum size of a CRL for Microsoft Entra ID to successfully download on an interactive sign-in is 20 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 45 MB in Azure US Government clouds. The time required to download the CRL must not exceed 10 seconds. If Microsoft Entra ID can't download a CRL, certificate-based authentications by using certificates issued by the corresponding CA fail. As a best practice to keep CRL files within size limits, keep certificate lifetimes within reasonable limits and clean up expired certificates.\n+\n+1. When a user performs an interactive sign-in with a certificate, Microsoft Entra ID downloads and caches the customer's certificate revocation list (CRL) from their certificate authority to check if certificates are revoked during the authentication of the user. Microsoft Entra uses the SubjectKeyIdentifier attribute instead of SubjectName to build the certificate chain. When CRLs are enabled, PKI configurations must include SubjectKeyIdentifier and Authority Key Identifier values to ensure proper revocation checking.\n+\n+   SubjectKeyIdentifier provides a unique, immutable identifier for the certificateâ€™s public key, making it more reliable than SubjectName, which can change or be duplicated across certificates. This attribute ensures accurate chain building and consistent CRL validation in complex PKI environments.\n+\n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >If an Authentication Policy Administrator skips the configuration of the CRL, Microsoft Entra ID doesn't perform any CRL checks during the certificate-based authentication of the user. This behavior can be helpful for initial troubleshooting, but shouldn't be considered for production use.\n+\n+   - Base CRL only: If only the base CRL is configured, Microsoft Entra ID downloads and caches it until the Next Update timestamp. Authentication fails if the CRL has expired and can't be refreshed due to connectivity issues or if the CRL endpoint doesn't provide an updated version. Microsoft Entra strictly enforces CRL versioning: when a new CRL is published, its CRL Number must be higher than the previous version.\n+\n+     CRL Number ensures monotonic versioning, preventing replay attacks where an older CRL could be reintroduced to bypass revocation checks. By requiring each new CRL to have a higher version number, Microsoft Entra ID guarantees that the most recent revocation data is always used.\n+\n+   - Base + Delta CRL: When both are configured, both must be valid and accessible. If either is missing or expired, certificate validation fails per RFC 5280 standards.\n+\n+1. The user certificate-based authentication fails if a CRL is configured for the trusted issuer and Microsoft Entra ID can't download the CRL, due to availability, size, or latency constraints. This limitation makes the CRL endpoint a critical single point of failure, reducing the resiliency of Microsoft Entra IDâ€™s certificate-based authentication. To mitigate this risk, we recommend using highly available solutions that ensure continuous uptime for CRL endpoints.\n+\n+1. If the CRL exceeds the interactive limit for a cloud, the user's initial sign-in fails with the following error:\n+\n+   `The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from {uri} has exceeded the maximum allowed size ({size} bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. Try again in few minutes. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.`\n+\n+1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download the CRL subject to the service-side limits (45 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 150 MB in Azure for US Government).\n+\n+1. Users can retry the authentication after a few minutes. If the user's certificate is revoked and appears in the CRL, the authentication fails.\n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >Token revocation for a revoked certificate isn't immediate because of CRL caching. If a CRL is already cached, newly revoked certificates aren't detected until the cache refreshes with an updated CRL. Delta CRLs typically include these updates, so revocation takes effect once the delta CRL is loaded. If delta CRLs aren't used, revocation depends on the base CRLâ€™s validity period. Administrators should manually revoke tokens only when immediate revocation is critical, such as in high-security scenarios. For more information, see [Configure revocation](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation).\n+\n+1. We don't support Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) because of performance and reliability reasons. Instead of downloading the CRL at every connection by the client browser for OCSP, Microsoft Entra ID downloads it once at the first sign-in and caches it. This action improves the performance and reliability of CRL verification. We also index the cache so the search is much faster every time. \n+\n+1. If Microsoft Entra successfully downloads the CRL, it caches and reuses the CRL for any subsequent usage. It honors the **Next update date** and, if available, **Next CRL Publish date** (used by Windows Server CAs) in the CRL document.\n+\n+\n+1. If the user's certificate is listed as revoked on the CRL, user authentication fails.\n+   \n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/user-cert.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the revoked user certificate in the CRL.\" ::: \n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >Due to the nature of CRL caching and publishing cycles, it's highly recommended that, if there's a certificate revocation, you also revoke all sessions of the affected user in Microsoft Entra ID.\n+\n+1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to pre-fetch a new CRL from the distribution point if the cached CRL document is expired. If CRL has a \"Next Publish Date\" Microsoft Entra does a CRL pre-fetch even if the CRL in cache is not expired. As of now, there's no way to manually force or retrigger the download of the CRL.\n+\n+   >[!NOTE]\n+   >Microsoft Entra ID checks the CRL of the issuing CA and other CAs in the PKI trust chain up to the root CA.    We have a limit of up to 10 CAs from the leaf client certificate for CRL validation in the PKI chain. The    limitation is to make sure a bad actor doesn't bring down the service by uploading a PKI chain with a huge    number of CAs with a bigger CRL size.\n+   >If the tenant's PKI chain has more than 10 CAs, and if there's a CA compromise, Authentication Policy Administrators should remove the compromised trusted issuer from the Microsoft Entra tenant configuration. For more information, see [CRL Pre-fetching](/windows/win32/seccrypto/certificate-revocation-list-semantics#crl-pre-fetching).\n+\n+### How to configure revocation\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [Configure revocation](../../includes/entra-authentication-configure-revocation.md)]\n+\n+## Enforce CRL validation for CAs\n+\n+When you upload CAs to the Microsoft Entra trust store, you don't need to include a CRL or the CrlDistributionPoint attribute. You can upload a CA without a CRL endpoint, and certificate-based authentication doesn't fail if an issuing CA doesn't specify a CRL. \n+\n+To strengthen security and avoid misconfigurations, an Authentication Policy Administrator can require CBA authentication to fail if a CA that issues an end user certificate doesn't configure a CRL.\n+\n+### Enable CRL validation\n+\n+1. Select **Require CRL validation (recommended)** to enable CRL validation. \n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/require-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to require CRL validation.\" :::  \n+   \n+   When you enable this setting, CBA fails if the end user certificate comes from a CA that doesn't configure a CRL.\n+\n+1. An Authentication Policy Administrator can exempt a CA if its CRL has issues that need to be fixed. Select **Add Exemption** and choose any CAs to exempt.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/exempt-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to exempt CAs from CRL validation.\" :::  \n+\n+1. CAs in the exempted list don't need to configure a CRL, and the end-user certificates they issue don't fail authentication.\n+\n+   Select CAs and select **Add**. Use the **Search** text box to filter the CA lists and select specific CAs.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/exempted.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of CAs that are exempted from CRL validation.\" ::: \n+\n+\n+## Guidance for setting up CRLs (base and delta CRL) for Microsoft Entra ID\n+\n+1. Publish accessible CRLs: \n+   - Ensure your CA publishes both the base CRL and delta CRLs (if applicable) to internet-facing URLs accessible via HTTP. \n+   - Microsoft Entra ID can't validate certificates if CRLs are hosted on internal-only servers. The URLs should be highly available, performant, and resilient to prevent authentication failures due to unavailability. \n+   - Validate CRL accessibility by testing the CRL URL in a browser and using certutil -url for distribution checks.\n+\n+1. Configure CRL URLs in Microsoft Entra ID: \n+   - Upload the CA public certificate to Microsoft Entra ID and configure the CRL distribution points (CDPs). \n+   - Base CRL URL: Contains all revoked certificates.\n+   - Delta CRL URL (optional but recommended): Contains certificates revoked since the last base CRL was    published.\n+   - Use tools like certutil to verify CRL validity and troubleshoot certificate and CRL issues locally.\n+   \n+\n+1. Set validity periods:\n+   - Set the base CRL validity period long enough to balance operational overhead and security (typically days to weeks).\n+   - Set the delta CRL validity period shorter (commonly 24 hours) to allow for timely recognition of revoked certificates.\n+   - Shorter delta CRL validity improves security by reducing the window where revoked certificates remain valid but increases issuance and distribution load.\n+   - The recommended 24-hour default validity for delta CRLs on Windows Servers is a widely accepted standard security and performance.\n+   - Microsoft Entra ID is designed to efficiently handle frequent delta CRL updates without performance    degradation, and ongoing improvements help enhance this further. \n+   - Microsoft Entra ID applies throttling mechanisms to protect against DDoS attacks during delta CRL downloads, which can result in temporary errors like \"AADSTS2205013\" for a small subset of users.\n+   \n+1. Ensure high availability and performance:\n+   - Host CRLs on reliable web servers or content delivery networks (CDNs) to minimize delays or failures during retrieval.\n+   - Monitor CRL publication and accessibility proactively.\n+   \n+1. Protect against throttling and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks:\n+   - To protect Microsoft Entra ID services and users, throttling is applied to CRL fetch operations during high load or potential abuse.\n+   - Schedule CRL publication and expiration cycles during off-peak hours to minimize the likelihood of    throttling impacting users.\n+   \n+1. CRL size management\n+   - Keep CRL payloads as small as possible, ideally by frequent delta CRL issuance and archival of old entries, to improve fetch speed and reduce bandwidth.\n+\n+1. Enable CRL validation\n+   - Enforce CRL validation in Microsoft Entra ID policies to ensure revoked certificates are detected. For more information, see [Enable CRL validation](concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md#enable-crl-validation).\n+   - Consider temporary bypass of CRL checking only as a last resort during troubleshooting, with an understanding of the security risks.\n+\n+1. Test and monitor\n+   - Perform regular tests to verify that CRLs are downloadable and recognized correctly by Microsoft Entra ID.\n+   - Use monitoring to detect and quickly remediate any CRL availability or validation issues.\n+   \n+## CRL error reference \n+\n+| Error code and message | Description | Common causes | Recommendations  |\n+|-------------------------|-------------|---------------|----------------------|\n+| **AADSTS500171: Certificate has been revoked. Please contact your administrator.**| Certificate is in the CRL, indicating it's revoked.   | Certificate is revoked by the admin. |   If a certificate is mistakenly included in the CRL, have the issuing CA reissue the CRL with an updated list that accurately reflects the intended revocations.      |\n+| **AADSTS500172: Certificate '{name}' issued by '{issuer}' is not valid. Current time: '{curTime}'. Certificate NotBefore: '{startTime}'. Certificate NotAfter: '{endTime}'.** | CRL isn't valid in time. | The CRLs or delta CRLs used to validate the certificate have timing issues such as expired CRLs or incorrectly configured publication/validity times.| - Confirm that the certificateâ€™s NotBefore and NotAfter dates properly encompass the current time.<br/>- Verify that the base and delta CRLs published by your CA aren't expired.    |\n+| **AADSTS500173: >Unable to download a Certificate Revocation List (CRL). Invalid status code {code} from CRL distribution point. Please contact your administrator.** | CRL couldn't be downloaded due to endpoint issues.  | - CRL endpoint returns HTTP errors (such as 403)<br>- CRL expired with no update | - Confirm CRL endpoint returns valid data<br>- Ensure CA regularly publishes updated CRLs<br> - The CRL URL is inaccessible due to network issues, firewall blocks, or server downtime.<br/>- Enable CRL fail-safe to block unverifiable certificates. |\n+| **AADSTS500174: Unable to construct valid Certificate Revocation List (CRL) from response.** |        Microsoft Entra ID can't parse or use the CRL retrieved from the specified distribution point.  | -  The CRL URL is inaccessible due to network issues, firewall blocks, or server downtime.  <br/>- The downloaded CRL file is corrupted, incomplete, or incorrectly formatted.<br/>-  The URLs in the certificateâ€™s CDP fields don't point to valid CRL files or are misconfigured.        |    - Verify CRL accessibility, validity, and integrity. <br/>-  Inspect the CRL file for corruption or incomplete content.   |\n+| **AADSTS500175: Revocation check failed because the Certificate Revocation List (CRL) for one certificate in the chain is missing.**         |    During certificate revocation checking, Microsoft Entra couldn't locate a required segment or portion of the Certificate Revocation List (CRL).            |     - The CRL file downloaded from the CRL Distribution Point (CDP) is corrupted or truncated.<br/>- Incorrect or incomplete publication of the CRL by the CA.<br/>- Network issues causing incomplete or failed CRL downloads.<br/>- Misconfiguration of the CRL distribution point URLs or file segments.                    |   - Verify CRL Integrity<br/>- Republish or Regenerate CRL <br/>- Check Network and Proxy Settings <br/>- Ensure Correct CDP Configuration on all the CAs      |\n+| **AADSTS500176: The certificate authority that issued your certificate hasn't been set up in the tenant. Automate CRL publication if possible.<br/>- Allow necessary network traffic to CRL distribution points by updating firewall, proxy, or security device rules.<br/>- Verify the downloaded CRLs for corruption or truncation, and republish if necessary.<br/>- Double-check Microsoft Entra ID and CA configurations related to CRL publishing, URLs, and validation policies.<br/>   |\n+| **AADSTS500178: Unable to retrieve valid CRL segments for {type}. Certificate listed in CRL           | - Replace revoked certificate<br>- Investigate revocation reason with CA<br>- Monitor certificate lifecycle and renewal       |\n+\n+\n+## Frequently asked questions\n+\n+This next sections cover common questions and answers related to Certificate Revocation Lists. \n+\n+### Is there a limit for CRL size?\n+        \n+The following CRL size limits apply: \n+\n+- Interactive sign-in download limit: 20 MB (Azure Global includes GCC), 45 MB for (Azure US government, includes GCC High, Dept. of Defense)\n+- Service download limit: 65 MB (Azure Global includes GCC), 150 MB for (Azure US government, includes GCC High, Dept. of Defense)\n+\n+When a CRL download fails, the following message appears: \n+    \n+\"The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from {uri} has exceeded the maximum allowed size ({size} bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. Try again in few minutes. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.\"\n+    \n+Download remains in the background with higher limits.\n+\n+We're reviewing the impact of these limits and have plans to remove them.\n+\n+### I see a valid Certificate Revocation List (CRL) endpoint set, but why don't I see any CRL revocation?\n+    \n+- Make sure the CRL distribution point is set to a valid HTTP URL.\n+- Make sure the CRL distribution point is accessible via an internet-facing URL.\n+- Make sure the CRL sizes are within limits. \n+\n+### How do I instantly revoke a certificate?\n+        \n+Follow the steps to [manually revoke a certificate](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation). \n+\n+### How can I turn certificate revocation checking on or off for a particular CA?\n+        \n+We recommend against disabling certificate revocation list (CRL) checking because you won't be able to revoke certificates. \n+However, if you need to investigate issues with CRL checking, you can exempt a CA from CRL checking in the Microsoft Entra admin center. \n+In the CBA Authentication methods policy, select **Configure** and then select **Add exemption**. Choose the CA that you want to exempt, and select **Add**. \n+\n+### After a CRL endpoint is configured, end users can't sign in and they see \"AADSTS500173: Unable to download CRL. Invalid status code Forbidden from CRL distribution point.\"\n+\n+When a problem prevents Microsoft Entra from downloading the CRL, the cause is often firewall restrictions. In most cases, you can resolve the issue by updating firewall rules to allow the required IP addresses so Microsoft Entra can successfully download the CRL. For more information, see [List of Microsoft IPAddress](/microsoft-365/enterprise/urls-and-ip-address-ranges#microsoft-365-unified-domains).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [Overview of Microsoft Entra CBA](concept-certificate-based-authentication.md)\n+- [How to configure Microsoft Entra CBA](how-to-certificate-based-authentication.md)\n+- [Microsoft Entra CBA on iOS devices](concept-certificate-based-authentication-mobile-ios.md)\n+- [Microsoft Entra CBA on Android devices](concept-certificate-based-authentication-mobile-android.md)\n+- [Windows smart card logon using Microsoft Entra CBA](concept-certificate-based-authentication-smartcard.md)\n+- [Certificate user IDs](concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificateuserids.md)\n+- [How to migrate federated users](concept-certificate-based-authentication-migration.md)\n+- [FAQ](certificate-based-authentication-faq.yml)\n+- [Troubleshoot Microsoft Entra CBA](./certificate-based-authentication-faq.yml)\n+"

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive.md?ref=4e6d4e16e5723a1aa97ab9f67e9761a97a19d7fc",
    "patch": "@@ -416,82 +416,8 @@ To sync an empty value:\n \n Ensure that CBA in each tenant is configured with the username bindings pointing to the `certificateUserIds` field for the field types that you mapped from the certificate. Now any of these users can present the certificate at sign-in. After the unique value from the certificate is validated against the `certificateUserIds` field, the user is successfully signed in.\n \n-## Certificate revocation process\n \n-The certificate revocation process allows an Authentication Policy Administrator to revoke a previously issued certificate from being used for future authentication. Certificate revocation doesn't revoke tokens that are already issued to the user. To manually revoke tokens, complete the steps described in  [Configure revocation](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation).\n-\n-Microsoft Entra ID downloads and caches your CRL from your CA to check whether certificates are revoked when the user authenticates.\n-\n-An Authentication Policy Administrator can configure the CRL distribution point during the setup process for trusted issuers in the Microsoft Entra tenant. Each trusted issuer should have a CRL that can be referenced by using an internet-facing URL.\n-\n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> The maximum size of a CRL for Microsoft Entra ID to successfully download on an interactive sign-in and cache is 20 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 45 MB in Azure US Government clouds. The time required to download the CRL must not exceed 10 seconds. If Microsoft Entra ID can't download a CRL, CBA that uses a certificate issued by the corresponding CA fails. As a best practice to keep CRL files within size limits, keep certificate lifetimes within reasonable limits and clean up expired certificates. For more information, see [Do CRLs have a size limit?](certificate-based-authentication-faq.yml#do-crls-have-a-size-limit-).\n-\n-When a user performs an interactive sign-in with a certificate and the CRL exceeds the interactive limit for a cloud, initial sign-in fails and shows the following error message:\n-\n-`\"The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from <URI> has exceeded the maximum allowed size (<size> bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. Try again in few minutes. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.\"`\n-\n-After the error, Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download the CRL subject to the service-side limits (45 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 150 MB in Azure US Government clouds).\n-\n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> If an Authentication Policy Administrator doesn't configure the CRL, Microsoft Entra ID doesn't perform any CRL checks during CBA for a user. This option can be helpful for initial troubleshooting, but don't use it in production.\n-\n-Currently, we don't support Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) for performance and reliability reasons. Instead of downloading the CRL for OCSP at each connection with the client browser, Microsoft Entra ID downloads it once at the first sign-in, and then caches it. This approach improves the performance and reliability of CRL verification. We also index the cache so that the search is faster. You must publish your CRLs for certificate revocation.\n-\n-The following steps describe the typical flow for a CRL check:\n-\n-1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download the CRL at the first sign-in event of any user with a certificate of the corresponding trusted issuer or CA.\n-1. Microsoft Entra ID caches and reuses the CRL for any subsequent usage. It honors the **Next update date** value and, if available, the **Next CRL Publish date** value (used by Windows Server CAs) in the CRL document.\n-\n-   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/user-cert.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows the revoked user certificate in the CRL.\" :::  \n-\n-1. User CBA fails if:\n-\n-   - A CRL is configured for the trusted issuer and Microsoft Entra ID can't download the CRL, due to availability, size, or latency constraints.\n-   - The user's certificate is listed as revoked on the CRL.\n-   - Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download a new CRL from the distribution point if the cached CRL document is expired.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Microsoft Entra ID checks the CRL of the issuing CA and other CAs in the public key infrastructure (PKI) trust chain up to the root CA. We have a limit of up to 10 CAs from the leaf client certificate for CRL validation in the PKI chain. The limitation is to ensure that a bad actor doesn't bring down the service by uploading a PKI chain that has a vast number of CAs and a larger CRL.\n->\n-> If the tenant's PKI chain has more than 5 CAs, and if there's a CA compromise, an Authentication Policy Administrator should remove the compromised trusted issuer from the Microsoft Entra tenant configuration.\n-\n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> Due to the nature of CRL caching and publishing cycles, we recommend that if a certificate is revoked, you also revoke all sessions of the affected user in Microsoft Entra ID.\n-\n-Currently, you can't manually force or retrigger a CRL download.\n-\n-### Configure revocation\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [Configure revocation](../../includes/entra-authentication-configure-revocation.md)]\n-\n-## CRL validation\n-\n-A CRL is a record of digital certificates that have been revoked by a CA before the end of their validity period.\n-\n-When CAs are uploaded to the Microsoft Entra trust store, a `CrlDistributionPoint` attribute isn't required. You can upload a CA without a CRL endpoint. CBA doesn't fail if an issuing CA doesn't specify a CRL.\n-\n-To strengthen security and avoid misconfigurations, an Authentication Policy Administrator can require CBA authentication to fail if no CRL is configured for a CA that issues a user certificate.\n-\n-### Turn on CRL validation\n-\n-To turn on CRL validation, select the **Require CRL validation (recommended)** checkbox.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/require-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows how to require CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-After you turn on CRL validation, any CBA failure occurs because the user certificate was issued by a CA that doesn't have a CRL configured.\n-\n-An Authentication Policy Administrator can exempt a CA if its CRL has issues that to fix. Select **Add Exemption**, and then select any CAs to exempt.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/exempt-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows how to exempt CAs from CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-The CAs in the exempted list aren't required to have a CRL configured, and the user certificates they issue don't fail authentication.\n-\n-Select CAs and select **Add**. You can use **Search** to filter the CA lists to select specific CAs.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/exempted.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows CAs that are exempted from CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-## CA scoping (preview)\n+## Certificate Authority (CA) Scoping (Preview)\n \n CA scoping in Microsoft Entra allows tenant administrators to restrict the use of specific CAs to defined user groups. This feature enhances the security and manageability of CBA by ensuring that only authorized users can authenticate by using certificates issued by specific CAs.\n "

ai_summary.Response:
These commits primarily update documentation related to Microsoft Entra's certificate-based authentication (CBA). Key changes include:

*   **Clarifying CRL Documentation:** Several files have been updated to point to a new or more specific article (`concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md`) for Certificate Revocation List (CRL) information, refining the details on how CRLs work, their configuration, and troubleshooting.
*   **PIM Audit Log Updates:** The documentation for viewing audit logs in Privileged Identity Management (PIM) has been updated with new screenshots and revised descriptions.
*   **Minor Link and Text Corrections:** A few other commits address minor link updates and text corrections across various documentation pages, including those for Entra Connect prerequisites.

To assist with this task, it's recommended to install the \n+          [MSIdentity Tools](https://aka.ms/msid) PowerShell module and run [Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration](https://github.com/AzureAD/MSIdentityTools/wiki/Test-MsIdCBATrustStoreConfiguration). \n+          This PowerShell cmdlet will review the Microsoft Entra tenant certificate authority configuration and surface errors/warnings for common mis-configuration issues. \n \n       - question: |\n           Do changes to the authentication methods policy take effect immediately?\n@@ -159,13 +123,7 @@ sections:\n \n            ```http\n            GET  https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/users?$filter=certificateUserIds/any(x:x eq 'bob@contoso.com')\n-           ```\n-\n-      - question: |\n-           After a CRL endpoint is configured, users can't sign in.     "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/30f504f4ab75f97044ac1911822d83b9a5b5b807/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md?ref=30f504f4ab75f97044ac1911822d83b9a5b5b807",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,236 @@\n+---\n+title: Understand Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication Certificate revocation list\n+description: Learn how certificate revocation list works with Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.subservice: authentication\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 08/26/2025\n+ms.author: justinha\n+author: vimrang\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.reviewer: vranganathan\n+ms.custom: has-adal-ref, sfi-image-nochange\n+ms.localizationpriority: high\n+---\n+\n+# Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication Certificate Revocation List (CRL)\n+\n+A Certificate Revocation List (CRL) is a list of certificates that have been revoked by the issuing Certificate Authority (CA) before their scheduled expiration date. CRLs are essential for maintaining authentication integrity. When a certificate is revoked, itâ€™s marked as untrusted even if not expired. Incorporating CRLs in certificate-based authentication ensures only valid, non-revoked certificates are accepted, and Microsoft Entra ID blocks any attempt using a revoked certificate.\n+\n+CRLs are digitally signed by the CA and published to publicly accessible locations, allowing them to be downloaded over the internet to verify the revocation status of certificates. When a client presents a certificate for authentication, the system checks the CRL to determine if the certificate has been revoked. \n+\n+If the certificate is found in the CRL, the authentication attempt is rejected. CRLs are usually updated periodically, and organizations should ensure they have the latest version of the CRL to make accurate decisions about certificate validity. \n+\n+In Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication (CBA), when CRLs are configured, the system must retrieve and validate the CRL during authentication. If Microsoft Entra ID cannot access the CRL endpoint, authentication fails because the CRL is required to confirm certificate validity.\n+\n+## How a CRL works in certificate-based authentication\n+\n+A CRL works by providing a mechanism to check the validity of certificates used for authentication. The process involves several key steps:\n+\n+- **Certificate Issuance:** When a certificate is issued by a CA, it is valid until its expiration date unless it is revoked earlier. Each certificate contains a public key and is signed by the CA.\n+- **Revocation:** If a certificate needs to be revoked (for example, if  the private key is compromised or the certificate is no longer needed), the CA adds it to the CRL.\n+- **CRL Distribution:** The CA publishes the CRL to a location accessible by clients, such as a web server or a directory service. The CRL is typically signed by the CA to ensure its integrity.\n+- **Client Check:** When a client presents a certificate for authentication, the system retrieves the CRL for each CA in the certificate chain from its published locations and checks for any revoked CAs. If any CRL location is unavailable, authentication fails because the system cannot verify the certificateâ€™s revocation status.\n+- **Authentication:** If the certificate is found in the CRL, the authentication attempt is rejected, and the client is denied access. If the certificate is not in the CRL, the authentication proceeds as normal.\n+- **CRL Updates:** The CRL is updated periodically by the CA, and clients should ensure they have the latest version to make accurate decisions about certificate validity. The system does cache the CRL for a certain period to reduce network traffic and improve performance, but it does also check for updates regularly.\n+\n+## Understanding the certificate revocation process in Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication\n+\n+The certificate revocation process enables Authentication Policy Administrators to revoke a previously issued certificate so it can't be used for future authentication. \n+\n+\n+Authentication Policy Administrators configure the CRL distribution point during the setup process for trusted issuers in the Microsoft Entra tenant. Each trusted issuer should have a CRL that you can reference by using an internet-facing URL. For more information, see [Configure Certificate Authorities](./how-to-certificate-based-authentication.md#step-1-configure-the-cas-with-a-pki-based-trust-store).\n+\n+Microsoft Entra ID supports only one CRL endpoint and supports only HTTP or HTTPS. We recommend using HTTP instead of HTTPS for CRL distribution. CRL checks occur during certificate-based authentication, and any delay or failure in retrieving the CRL can block authentication. Using HTTP minimizes latency and avoids potential circular dependencies caused by HTTPS (which itself requires certificate validation). To ensure reliability, host CRLs on highly available HTTP endpoints and verify that they're accessible over the internet.\n+ \n+>[!IMPORTANT]\n+>The maximum size of a CRL for Microsoft Entra ID to successfully download on an interactive sign-in is 20 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 45 MB in Azure US Government clouds. The time required to download the CRL must not exceed 10 seconds. If Microsoft Entra ID can't download a CRL, certificate-based authentications by using certificates issued by the corresponding CA fail. As a best practice to keep CRL files within size limits, keep certificate lifetimes within reasonable limits and clean up expired certificates.\n+\n+1. When a user performs an interactive sign-in with a certificate, Microsoft Entra ID downloads and caches the customer's certificate revocation list (CRL) from their certificate authority to check if certificates are revoked during the authentication of the user. Microsoft Entra uses the SubjectKeyIdentifier attribute instead of SubjectName to build the certificate chain. When CRLs are enabled, PKI configurations must include SubjectKeyIdentifier and Authority Key Identifier values to ensure proper revocation checking.\n+\n+   SubjectKeyIdentifier provides a unique, immutable identifier for the certificateâ€™s public key, making it more reliable than SubjectName, which can change or be duplicated across certificates. This attribute ensures accurate chain building and consistent CRL validation in complex PKI environments.\n+\n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >If an Authentication Policy Administrator skips the configuration of the CRL, Microsoft Entra ID doesn't perform any CRL checks during the certificate-based authentication of the user. This behavior can be helpful for initial troubleshooting, but shouldn't be considered for production use.\n+\n+   - Base CRL only: If only the base CRL is configured, Microsoft Entra ID downloads and caches it until the Next Update timestamp. Authentication fails if the CRL has expired and can't be refreshed due to connectivity issues or if the CRL endpoint doesn't provide an updated version. Microsoft Entra strictly enforces CRL versioning: when a new CRL is published, its CRL Number must be higher than the previous version.\n+\n+     CRL Number ensures monotonic versioning, preventing replay attacks where an older CRL could be reintroduced to bypass revocation checks. By requiring each new CRL to have a higher version number, Microsoft Entra ID guarantees that the most recent revocation data is always used.\n+\n+   - Base + Delta CRL: When both are configured, both must be valid and accessible. If either is missing or expired, certificate validation fails per RFC 5280 standards.\n+\n+1. The user certificate-based authentication fails if a CRL is configured for the trusted issuer and Microsoft Entra ID can't download the CRL, due to availability, size, or latency constraints. This limitation makes the CRL endpoint a critical single point of failure, reducing the resiliency of Microsoft Entra IDâ€™s certificate-based authentication. To mitigate this risk, we recommend using highly available solutions that ensure continuous uptime for CRL endpoints.\n+\n+1. If the CRL exceeds the interactive limit for a cloud, the user's initial sign-in fails with the following error:\n+\n+   `The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from {uri} has exceeded the maximum allowed size ({size} bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. Try again in few minutes. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.`\n+\n+1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download the CRL subject to the service-side limits (45 MB in public Microsoft Entra ID and 150 MB in Azure for US Government).\n+\n+1. Users can retry the authentication after a few minutes. If the user's certificate is revoked and appears in the CRL, the authentication fails.\n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >Token revocation for a revoked certificate isn't immediate because of CRL caching. If a CRL is already cached, newly revoked certificates aren't detected until the cache refreshes with an updated CRL. Delta CRLs typically include these updates, so revocation takes effect once the delta CRL is loaded. If delta CRLs aren't used, revocation depends on the base CRLâ€™s validity period. Administrators should manually revoke tokens only when immediate revocation is critical, such as in high-security scenarios. For more information, see [Configure revocation](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation).\n+\n+1. We don't support Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) because of performance and reliability reasons. Instead of downloading the CRL at every connection by the client browser for OCSP, Microsoft Entra ID downloads it once at the first sign-in and caches it. This action improves the performance and reliability of CRL verification. We also index the cache so the search is much faster every time. \n+\n+1. If Microsoft Entra successfully downloads the CRL, it caches and reuses the CRL for any subsequent usage. It honors the **Next update date** and, if available, **Next CRL Publish date** (used by Windows Server CAs) in the CRL document.\n+\n+\n+1. If the user's certificate is listed as revoked on the CRL, user authentication fails.\n+   \n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/user-cert.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the revoked user certificate in the CRL.\" ::: \n+\n+   >[!IMPORTANT]\n+   >Due to the nature of CRL caching and publishing cycles, it's highly recommended that, if there's a certificate revocation, you also revoke all sessions of the affected user in Microsoft Entra ID.\n+\n+1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to pre-fetch a new CRL from the distribution point if the cached CRL document is expired. If CRL has a \"Next Publish Date\" Microsoft Entra does a CRL pre-fetch even if the CRL in cache is not expired. As of now, there's no way to manually force or retrigger the download of the CRL.\n+\n+   >[!NOTE]\n+   >Microsoft Entra ID checks the CRL of the issuing CA and other CAs in the PKI trust chain up to the root CA.    We have a limit of up to 10 CAs from the leaf client certificate for CRL validation in the PKI chain. The    limitation is to make sure a bad actor doesn't bring down the service by uploading a PKI chain with a huge    number of CAs with a bigger CRL size.\n+   >If the tenant's PKI chain has more than 10 CAs, and if there's a CA compromise, Authentication Policy Administrators should remove the compromised trusted issuer from the Microsoft Entra tenant configuration. For more information, see [CRL Pre-fetching](/windows/win32/seccrypto/certificate-revocation-list-semantics#crl-pre-fetching).\n+\n+### How to configure revocation\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [Configure revocation](../../includes/entra-authentication-configure-revocation.md)]\n+\n+## Enforce CRL validation for CAs\n+\n+When you upload CAs to the Microsoft Entra trust store, you don't need to include a CRL or the CrlDistributionPoint attribute. You can upload a CA without a CRL endpoint, and certificate-based authentication doesn't fail if an issuing CA doesn't specify a CRL. \n+\n+To strengthen security and avoid misconfigurations, an Authentication Policy Administrator can require CBA authentication to fail if a CA that issues an end user certificate doesn't configure a CRL.\n+\n+### Enable CRL validation\n+\n+1. Select **Require CRL validation (recommended)** to enable CRL validation. \n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/require-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to require CRL validation.\" :::  \n+   \n+   When you enable this setting, CBA fails if the end user certificate comes from a CA that doesn't configure a CRL.\n+\n+1. An Authentication Policy Administrator can exempt a CA if its CRL has issues that need to be fixed. Select **Add Exemption** and choose any CAs to exempt.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/exempt-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to exempt CAs from CRL validation.\" :::  \n+\n+1. CAs in the exempted list don't need to configure a CRL, and the end-user certificates they issue don't fail authentication.\n+\n+   Select CAs and select **Add**. Use the **Search** text box to filter the CA lists and select specific CAs.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list/exempted.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of CAs that are exempted from CRL validation.\" ::: \n+\n+\n+## Guidance for setting up CRLs (base and delta CRL) for Microsoft Entra ID\n+\n+1. Publish accessible CRLs: \n+   - Ensure your CA publishes both the base CRL and delta CRLs (if applicable) to internet-facing URLs accessible via HTTP. \n+   - Microsoft Entra ID can't validate certificates if CRLs are hosted on internal-only servers. The URLs should be highly available, performant, and resilient to prevent authentication failures due to unavailability. \n+   - Validate CRL accessibility by testing the CRL URL in a browser and using certutil -url for distribution checks.\n+\n+1. Configure CRL URLs in Microsoft Entra ID: \n+   - Upload the CA public certificate to Microsoft Entra ID and configure the CRL distribution points (CDPs). \n+   - Base CRL URL: Contains all revoked certificates.\n+   - Delta CRL URL (optional but recommended): Contains certificates revoked since the last base CRL was    published.\n+   - Use tools like certutil to verify CRL validity and troubleshoot certificate and CRL issues locally.\n+   \n+\n+1. Set validity periods:\n+   - Set the base CRL validity period long enough to balance operational overhead and security (typically days to weeks).\n+   - Set the delta CRL validity period shorter (commonly 24 hours) to allow for timely recognition of revoked certificates.\n+   - Shorter delta CRL validity improves security by reducing the window where revoked certificates remain valid but increases issuance and distribution load.\n+   - The recommended 24-hour default validity for delta CRLs on Windows Servers is a widely accepted standard security and performance.\n+   - Microsoft Entra ID is designed to efficiently handle frequent delta CRL updates without performance    degradation, and ongoing improvements help enhance this further. \n+   - Microsoft Entra ID applies throttling mechanisms to protect against DDoS attacks during delta CRL downloads, which can result in temporary errors like \"AADSTS2205013\" for a small subset of users.\n+   \n+1. Ensure high availability and performance:\n+   - Host CRLs on reliable web servers or content delivery networks (CDNs) to minimize delays or failures during retrieval.\n+   - Monitor CRL publication and accessibility proactively.\n+   \n+1. Protect against throttling and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks:\n+   - To protect Microsoft Entra ID services and users, throttling is applied to CRL fetch operations during high load or potential abuse.\n+   - Schedule CRL publication and expiration cycles during off-peak hours to minimize the likelihood of    throttling impacting users.\n+   \n+1. CRL size management\n+   - Keep CRL payloads as small as possible, ideally by frequent delta CRL issuance and archival of old entries, to improve fetch speed and reduce bandwidth.\n+\n+1. Enable CRL validation\n+   - Enforce CRL validation in Microsoft Entra ID policies to ensure revoked certificates are detected. For more information, see [Enable CRL validation](concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md#enable-crl-validation).\n+   - Consider temporary bypass of CRL checking only as a last resort during troubleshooting, with an understanding of the security risks.\n+\n+1. Test and monitor\n+   - Perform regular tests to verify that CRLs are downloadable and recognized correctly by Microsoft Entra ID.\n+   - Use monitoring to detect and quickly remediate any CRL availability or validation issues.\n+   \n+## CRL error reference \n+\n+| Error code and message | Description | Common causes | Recommendations  |\n+|-------------------------|-------------|---------------|----------------------|\n+| **AADSTS500171: Certificate has been revoked. Certificate listed in CRL           | - Replace revoked certificate<br>- Investigate revocation reason with CA<br>- Monitor certificate lifecycle and renewal       |\n+\n+\n+## Frequently asked questions\n+\n+This next sections cover common questions and answers related to Certificate Revocation Lists. \n+\n+### Is there a limit for CRL size?\n+        \n+The following CRL size limits apply: \n+\n+- Interactive sign-in download limit: 20 MB (Azure Global includes GCC), 45 MB for (Azure US government, includes GCC High, Dept. of Defense)\n+- Service download limit: 65 MB (Azure Global includes GCC), 150 MB for (Azure US government, includes GCC High, Dept. of Defense)\n+\n+When a CRL download fails, the following message appears: \n+    \n+\"The Certificate Revocation List (CRL) downloaded from {uri} has exceeded the maximum allowed size ({size} bytes) for CRLs in Microsoft Entra ID. Try again in few minutes. If the issue persists, contact your tenant administrators.\"\n+    \n+Download remains in the background with higher limits.\n+\n+We're reviewing the impact of these limits and have plans to remove them.\n+\n+### I see a valid Certificate Revocation List (CRL) endpoint set, but why don't I see any CRL revocation?\n+    \n+- Make sure the CRL distribution point is set to a valid HTTP URL.\n+- Make sure the CRL distribution point is accessible via an internet-facing URL.\n+- Make sure the CRL sizes are within limits. \n+\n+### How do I instantly revoke a certificate?\n+        \n+Follow the steps to [manually revoke a certificate](./certificate-based-authentication-federation-get-started.md#step-3-configure-revocation). \n+\n+### How can I turn certificate revocation checking on or off for a particular CA?\n+        \n+We recommend against disabling certificate revocation list (CRL) checking because you won't be able to revoke certificates. \n+However, if you need to investigate issues with CRL checking, you can exempt a CA from CRL checking in the Microsoft Entra admin center. \n+In the CBA Authentication methods policy, select **Configure** and then select **Add exemption**. Choose the CA that you want to exempt, and select **Add**. \n+\n+### After a CRL endpoint is configured, end users can't sign in and they see \"AADSTS500173: Unable to download CRL. Invalid status code Forbidden from CRL distribution point.\"\n+\n+When a problem prevents Microsoft Entra from downloading the CRL, the cause is often firewall restrictions. In most cases, you can resolve the issue by updating firewall rules to allow the required IP addresses so Microsoft Entra can successfully download the CRL. Instead of downloading the CRL for OCSP at each connection with the client browser, Microsoft Entra ID downloads it once at the first sign-in, and then caches it. This approach improves the performance and reliability of CRL verification. We also index the cache so that the search is faster. You must publish your CRLs for certificate revocation.\n-\n-The following steps describe the typical flow for a CRL check:\n-\n-1. Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download the CRL at the first sign-in event of any user with a certificate of the corresponding trusted issuer or CA.\n-1. Microsoft Entra ID caches and reuses the CRL for any subsequent usage. It honors the **Next update date** value and, if available, the **Next CRL Publish date** value (used by Windows Server CAs) in the CRL document.\n-\n-   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/user-cert.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows the revoked user certificate in the CRL.\" :::  \n-\n-1. User CBA fails if:\n-\n-   - A CRL is configured for the trusted issuer and Microsoft Entra ID can't download the CRL, due to availability, size, or latency constraints.\n-   - The user's certificate is listed as revoked on the CRL.\n-   - Microsoft Entra ID attempts to download a new CRL from the distribution point if the cached CRL document is expired.\n-\n-> [!NOTE]\n-> Microsoft Entra ID checks the CRL of the issuing CA and other CAs in the public key infrastructure (PKI) trust chain up to the root CA. We have a limit of up to 10 CAs from the leaf client certificate for CRL validation in the PKI chain. The limitation is to ensure that a bad actor doesn't bring down the service by uploading a PKI chain that has a vast number of CAs and a larger CRL.\n->\n-> If the tenant's PKI chain has more than 5 CAs, and if there's a CA compromise, an Authentication Policy Administrator should remove the compromised trusted issuer from the Microsoft Entra tenant configuration.\n-\n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> Due to the nature of CRL caching and publishing cycles, we recommend that if a certificate is revoked, you also revoke all sessions of the affected user in Microsoft Entra ID.\n-\n-Currently, you can't manually force or retrigger a CRL download.\n-\n-### Configure revocation\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [Configure revocation](../../includes/entra-authentication-configure-revocation.md)]\n-\n-## CRL validation\n-\n-A CRL is a record of digital certificates that have been revoked by a CA before the end of their validity period.\n-\n-When CAs are uploaded to the Microsoft Entra trust store, a `CrlDistributionPoint` attribute isn't required. You can upload a CA without a CRL endpoint. CBA doesn't fail if an issuing CA doesn't specify a CRL.\n-\n-To strengthen security and avoid misconfigurations, an Authentication Policy Administrator can require CBA authentication to fail if no CRL is configured for a CA that issues a user certificate.\n-\n-### Turn on CRL validation\n-\n-To turn on CRL validation, select the **Require CRL validation (recommended)** checkbox.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/require-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows how to require CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-After you turn on CRL validation, any CBA failure occurs because the user certificate was issued by a CA that doesn't have a CRL configured.\n-\n-An Authentication Policy Administrator can exempt a CA if its CRL has issues that to fix. Select **Add Exemption**, and then select any CAs to exempt.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/exempt-validation.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows how to exempt CAs from CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-The CAs in the exempted list aren't required to have a CRL configured, and the user certificates they issue don't fail authentication.\n-\n-Select CAs and select **Add**. You can use **Search** to filter the CA lists to select specific CAs.\n-\n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-certificate-based-authentication-technical-deep-dive/exempted.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows CAs that are exempted from CRL validation.\" :::  \n-\n-## CA scoping (preview)\n+## Certificate Authority (CA) Scoping (Preview)\n \n CA scoping in Microsoft Entra allows tenant administrators to restrict the use of specific CAs to defined user groups. This feature enhances the security and manageability of CBA by ensuring that only authorized users can authenticate by using certificates issued by specific CAs.\n "
  },

This set of commits primarily focuses on refining the documentation around Microsoft Entra's Certificate-Based Authentication (CBA). Key changes include:

*   **Consolidating CRL Information:** The documentation regarding Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs) has been moved and expanded into a dedicated page (`concept-certificate-based-authentication-certificate-revocation-list.md`), providing a comprehensive overview of their function, configuration, and error handling.

*   **Minor Corrections and Enhancements:** Some minor edits have been made to existing pages, such as updating references within the "What's New" sections and the technical deep dive for CBA.

Overall, these changes aim to improve the clarity and organisation of documentation related to CRLs in Microsoft Entra CBA.

Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Privileged Role Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#privileged-role-administrator).\n+1. ai_summary.Response:
This commit primarily updates the documentation for installing prerequisites for Microsoft Entra Connect.

The date of the article has been advanced to August 28, 2025. Additionally, a hyperlink to TLS 1.2 support for Microsoft SQL Server has been corrected, and the specific versions of Microsoft SQL Server command-line utilities, Express LocalDB, and Native Client have been updated from SQL Server 2022 to SQL Server 2019.
